english: to come; to arrive; future/next; used after a verb to indicate direction/result

etymology.description: Pictogram (象形) of wheat; later borrowed for “to come”.
etymology.interpretation: Originally a drawing of a wheat plant, with the central ear and upward leaves, plus lines for stem and roots. The sense “to come” is a semantic loan; scribes sometimes added motion-related elements like 止 or 辵 in early periods to mark the new meaning, but those additions did not persist.
etymology.simplification: The simplified form 来 adopts a long-used abbreviated/clerical variant of 來, reducing strokes by collapsing and streamlining the original wheat-shaped elements.

examples.chinese: 他明天来北京(他明天來北京)。
examples.english: He will come to Beijing tomorrow.

examples.chinese: 我们来年再见(我們來年再見)。
把那本书拿过来(把那本書拿過來)。
examples.pinyin: Bǎ nà běn shū ná guòlai.
